I.  THE PROPOSAL
1.  I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan to the Kingdom of Bhutan for the Basic Skills Development Project. The Government of
Germany will finance part of the Project, on a parallel basis, through the German Agency for
Technical Cooperation (GTZ).1
II.  INTRODUCTION
2.  The Royal Government of the Kingdom of Bhutan established skills training institutes as
part  of  its  program  to  modernize  the  education  system  in  the  early  1960s.  The  Asian
Development Bank (ADB) has provided assistance since the mid-1980s to the technical and
vocational education and training (TVET) sector in, for example, establishing the Royal Institute
of Management2 and expanding the Royal Bhutan Polytechnic to improve the quality of training
and double the intake capacity.3 Following ADB-initiated policy dialogue in the 1990s, the
Government embarked on reform of the TVET sector to meet the needs of an economy in
transition  to  a  modern,  private-sector-led  market  economy,  and  established  the  National
Technical Training Authority (NTTA) in 1999, as recommended in ADB technical assistance.4
During  the  initial  operation  of  NTTA,  the  Government  recognized  the  urgent  need  for
employment-oriented skills training at the basic level and requested ADB financial assistance to
prepare the Basic Skills Development Project. The project preparatory technical assistance
(PPTA) was approved in December 1999 and implemented between June and December 2000.
The Fact-Finding Mission from 8 to 19 January 2001 and the Appraisal Mission5 from 15 March
to 2 April 2001 visited Bhutan to formulate the Project on the basis of consultations on the
project feasibility report with NTTA and other Government agencies, representatives of the
beneficiaries (parents, students, and future employers), nongovernment organizations (NGOs),
and international aid agencies, as well as extensive site visits by staff during the PPTA review.
The project framework is in Appendix 1.

4.  In the 1950s, fewer than 450 children attended secular primary schools, and there were
no secondary schools. In 1961, the First Five-Year Plan (1FYP) initiated a comprehensive
education  system  for  the  country.  Since  then,  enrollments  at  all  levels  have  grown  at  an
impressive rate as a result of the Government’s commitment to develop the education sector.
Between 1984 and 1996, the adult literacy rate increased from 28 percent to 54 percent, and
the primary school gross enrollment rate (grades 1-6) rose from only 12 percent in 1980 to 72
percent in 1996. The Government is targeting a 95 percent enrollment rate in primary schools
under the 8FYP (1997-2002), and full enrollment at junior high school (grade 8) by 2007, at the
end of the 9FYP. In 1999, over 107,000 students were enrolled in the general education system
consisting of 254 primary and community schools, 51 junior high schools, 21 high schools, 7
private schools, and 10 other institutions providing specialized education as well as tertiary and
vocational  training.  Since  1997,  the  number  of  teachers  has  trebled  and  the  number  of
educational establishments has doubled. Throughout this development, the education sector
has aimed to improve the gender balance. Currently, the ratios in favor of boys are about 55:45
in primary schools, 53:47 in junior high schools, 57:43 in high schools, and 52:48 in private
schools.7 In 1996, the female primary school enrollment rate was about 60 percent.
5.  The Department of Education (DOE) of the Ministry of Health and Education (MOHE),
administers Bhutan’s current general educational system. While DOE directly administers higher
education, direct financial and administrative responsibility for primary and secondary schools
has been devolved to the dzongkhag (district) administrations. Formal schooling begins at the
age of six and is offered free of charge up to the tertiary level (except in seven private schools).
In the public schools system, the Government provides textbooks and, in some places, boarding
facilities and meals. Rural primary and junior high school students also receive free stationery.
Communities  in  rural  areas  contribute  labor  for  building  and  maintaining  their  schools.
Notwithstanding the contribution by individuals/families, the Government bears over 90 percent
of the recurrent costs of all schools, and 80 percent of the capital costs of primary schools and
100 percent of secondary schools.8
6.  Due to the increasing need to meet the critical shortage of secondary school facilities
and competent teachers as a result of the almost full primary school enrollment by 2002, the
Government recognizes that it cannot continue to support a free education system for all.
Consequently, the establishment of private schools is being encouraged as more families are
able to afford the cost of educating their children. The Government is aware that development of
private schools should not lead to a decline in the quality of public schools. The introduction of
more  cost  sharing  by  beneficiaries  in  addition  to  the  conventional  community  contribution,
particularly  at  the  post  junior  high  school  levels,  will  show  the  direction  to  cost  recovery
measures for a new TVET system. The much higher cost per capita of TVET, compared with
that of general education, indicates the importance of developing a cost recovery mechanism for
various training activities. Upon completion of junior high school, students, depending on their
performance, can proceed to high school or to a skills training institute such as the Royal
Technical  Institute,  which  offers  three  to  four  years  training.  Subject  to  their  academic
performance, high school graduates can choose the Royal Bhutan Polytechnic, a junior college,
a teacher training college, or other higher education institutes.

2.  Technical and Vocational Education and Training System
7.  The  Government  established  NTTA  in  May  1999  to  coordinate  the  national  TVET
system. The objectives of NTTA are to effectively respond to the acute need to create an
employable indigenous labor force, and to reform the TVET sector to create a private-sector-
oriented  TVET  system  in  Bhutan.  To  complement  the  reform  of  the  TVET  sector,  the
Government also established the National Employment Board (NEB) in March 2000 with the
mandate of regulating and administering the labor market. The mandate includes preparing
labor legislation, providing employment services, supervising labor relations and doing labor
market research.
8.  Before the establishment of NTTA, the Technical and Vocational Education Section
under DOE coordinated the training programs. The relatively large capacity of the public sector
to absorb all employment in the past—which partly explains the current aspirations of educated
youth to become civil servants, and the underdevelopment of the private sector-served the
purpose of the conventional TVET system to prepare students for a career in the public sector
agencies.  Consequently,  the  Royal  Civil  Service  Commission  (RCSC)  administered  job
placements for the public sector agencies, but there was no agency to facilitate private sector
employment. There was also no central agency to coordinate a national TVET system, involving
the formulation and planning of a skills development policy, skills standardization, testing and
certification,  and  training  program  accreditation.  Despite  the  Government  commitment  to
develop the private sector, lack of these capabilities constrains the promotion of private training
institutes in the TVET sector or in-house staff development programs run by individual private
enterprises.
9.  NTTA,  in  collaboration  with  NEB  and  other  ministries  concerned,  is  mandated  to
establish  an  employment-oriented  TVET  system.  NTTA  needs  to  (i)  formulate  skills
development and utilization policies and frameworks; (ii) replace outdated training programs that
have  little  relevance  to  the  emerging  labor  market  needs;  (iii)  improve  access  to  training
programs, particularly for women and the poor in rural areas; and (iv) provide access to skills
testing/certification for workers who wish to certify their skills attainment. There is also an urgent
need to coordinate and strengthen the employment counseling services for school graduates or
job placement services, which are currently handled by MOHE as well as by NEB and are
relatively  weak  compared  with  similar  services  provided  by  the  RCSC  for  public  sector
employment.
10.  The institutional capacity of NTTA and NEB is still inadequate to properly follow the
above mandates and better serve their priority clientele, comprising school graduates (grade 8
and  above),  existing  workers,  and  private  sector  employers  who  will  pay  for  the  trained
Bhutanese youth under the new TVET system. An institutional diagnostic analysis made by the
PPTA9 indicated the (i) lack of coherent TVET policies and associated employment policies,
qualified staff, skills, and management system to develop and administer the employment-
oriented skills training system, and mechanisms to maintain linkages with the private sector and
to deliver the training programs through various modalities; (ii) outdated and insufficient facilities
in the existing training institutes; (iii) weak interministerial coordination to institutionalize the
TVET system as part of the national human resource development framework; and (iv) lack of

11.  NTTA inherited five skills training institutes, including (i) the Royal Technical Institute
(RTI),10 which has been training young people since 1986 to be skilled tradesmen and trades
supervisors, most of whom worked for the Government services. Almost all training was for
formal four-year certificate level; skilled trades courses (comprising 60 percent practical and 40
percent  theoretical  training)  in  electrical,  mechanical,  and  automotive  engineering,  building
construction, and drafting; entry level was normally after graduating from junior high school at
grade 8; (ii) the Royal Bhutan Polytechnic (RBP), which has provided, since 1974, a three-year
diploma course for students graduating from high school at grade 10; (iii) the National Drivers
Training Institute (NDTI), which has provided, since 1989, a one-year program in vehicle driving
and basic maintenance; most of the trainees obtained employment with government agencies;
(iv) the National Institute for Zorig Chusum (NIZC), which has provided, since 1971, 3- to 5-year
courses on traditional arts and craft skills, including basic education subjects for those aged 14
and above and who have completed primary school; and (v) the Trashiyangtse Institute for Zorig
Chusum (TIZC),11 which has provided, since 1997, similar courses on traditional arts and craft
skills and, depending on the required skills, two-year advanced courses. The RTI is the most
relevant institute for basic skills development because of its location in Kharbandi near the
industrial sites and its relatively wider training curriculum.
12.  The site of these institutes was determined mainly on the basis of their access to (i)
industry and the teaching faculty (RTI and RBP), (ii) the market (NIZC), and (iii) raw materials
(TIZC).  Unfortunately,  the  location  was  not  always  convenient  to  students,  particularly  for
females  in  rural  areas.  However,  with  the  development  of  new  infrastructure  in  the  rural
electrification,12 telecommunication, and road sectors,13 new business opportunities will open up
to provide greater access to the training institutes and improve social services for villagers. The
PPTA recommended that the TVET system be expanded by providing regional training hubs
and mobile training teams capable of reaching local communities in rural areas. The reform of
NDTI, another PPTA recommendation, is important because the improved road networks are
generating demand for drivers due to the unprecedented growth in industry and for the self-
employed businesses in domestic transport, and freight - handling and distribution.
13.  The  Government  has  piloted  various  modalities  for  delivering  skills  training.  One
modality is the village skills development programs that already cover 700 villagers through
nonformal training programs comprising not only commonly required skills such as plumbing,
carpentry,  and  mechanical  repairs,  but  also  village-specific  skills  to  enhance  the
competitiveness of products in the local communities.
14.  Other public institutions under various ministries and agencies offer in-country training
opportunities, including the Royal Institute of Management, the National Institute of Traditional
Medicine, the Bhutan Forestry Institute in Thimphu, and the Natural Resource Training Institute.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Department of Tourism, and other ministries also offer short-term
basic skills training courses mostly for their staff. The National Women’s Association of Bhutan
(NWAB), established in 1981, provides nonformal training for skills development associated with
microcredit schemes. NWAB also established several small-scale training centers for weaving

16.  To decide the most cost-effective approach to establish a strategic location for a TVET

3.  Demand for Skills Training14
17.  Since  the  early  1960s,  Bhutan  has  implemented  policies  to  shift  from  a  traditional
economy to a modern, market-based economy. In the last two decades, Bhutan's economy
grew in real terms at the annual rate of 8.0 percent in the later part of the 1980s, 5.6 percent
from  1991  to  1995,  and  6.0  percent  from  1996  to  1999,  due  to  industrialization  and
diversification of its economic activities. Agriculture declined from a share of 53 percent of the
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  in  1981  to  37  percent  in  1998;  and  industry,  led  by
manufacturing, electricity, and construction, increased from 17 percent in 1981 to more than 35
percent in 1998. Since the second half of the 1980s, private sector development was a priority
of the Government and major State-owned enterprises were privatized. The buoyant growth of
the industry sector in the 1980s and 1990s created increasing demand for modern skilled and
semiskilled  workers.  Although  the  Government  had  given  high  priority  to  human  resource
development, particularly in the general education sector to support its modernization program,
domestic skilled human resources were not well-developed. To meet the rapidly increasing
demand from the industry sector, the Government resorted to the large pool of migrant workers
from neighboring countries to fill the vacancies of skilled, semiskilled, and unskilled workers.

18.  The PPTA survey indicated that about 50,000 expatriate workers already occupy skilled
and semiskilled jobs. With the Government’s continued emphasis on private sector development
under the 8FYP (1997-2002) and 9FYP (2003-2007), about 3,500 new jobs are forecast to be
created  each  year  in  the  industry  sector  in  the  foreseeable  future.  The  magnitude  of  the
potential job opportunities for Bhutanese workers is apparent. If the pace of economic growth
and industrialization continues without the participation of educated Bhutanese in the workforce,
the country will face a major dilemma of unemployment and underemployment in the near
future. Already, signs show increasing urban unemployment. Development of human resources,
particularly employable skills, is therefore a priority national issue.15 However, the country still
lacks the relevant training facilities, labor administration system for private sector employment,
and an effective labor market monitoring system. Lack of reliable statistics makes it difficult to
assess the domestic labor market.
19.  Based on  Bhutan's  official  population  estimate  of  638,000  in  1998,  the  labor  force
comprised about 54 percent (345,000) at age 15-59 and about 42 percent (268,000) below age
15. Both sexes in the category below age 15 have access to basic education. Primary education
enrollments in 1996 were 72 percent and are steadily increasing to 95 percent, the current
target under the 8FYP (1997-2002). As a result, about 4,200 students from grades 8-10 are
expected to graduate in 2001.16
20.  Despite the increasing number of educated youth coming into the labor market, it will
take time to improve the employability of graduates in the areas of traditional and modern skills,
particularly  in  the  service,  maintenance,  small-  and  medium-scale  manufacturing,  and
construction  sectors.  This  is  mainly  because  private  sector  employers  do  not  believe  the
graduates have adequate qualifications, including practical skills and job-related experience.17
Moreover, despite signs of change due to the difficulties in getting jobs, graduates have been
reluctant to join the private sector due to their traditional career preference for a high-status,
white-collar occupation in the public sector. This mismatch of expectations between employers
and job seekers has been further aggravated by the relatively less attractive working conditions
in the private sector than in the public sector and the different salary structures. The public
sector has a relatively flat salary structure, whereas the private sector has entry-level salaries
that are much lower initially but have greater potential for growth depending on individual
performance.
21.  Due to the difference in expectations between job seekers and employers, the influx of
educated youth onto the labor market is already resulting in urban youth unemployment and
unfilled vacancies in the private sector. The PPTA report on employment patterns and job
opportunities in July-August 2000 indicated that, of about 53,000 positions that could be suitably
filled by grade 8 and 10 graduates, 4,800 in various occupations were vacant. On the other

4.  Poverty, Human Resource, and Gender Issues20
24.  As with some other economic indicators in Bhutan, reliable data on incomes are not
available. The United Nations (UN) classified Bhutan among the least developed countries,
ranking it as 142nd out of 174 countries in the human development index (HDI) in 1998.

system of lending/borrowing food during the off-season helps the poorer families, as does the
Bhutan Food Corporation’s “fair price” shops and access to natural produce grown in forests.
Primary health care and medical services, and basic education are provided free. With this
social background, poverty is not as abject as in other parts of South Asia.

5.  Key Issues
28.  The most vexing labor market issue is that, despite vacancies in the labor market,
Bhutanese youth have difficulty finding employment after completing their general education
because they lack employable skills and their traditional preference is for employment in the
public service. Employers are dissatisfied with the skills attainment of Bhutanese youth and
therefore fill vacancies with expatriate laborers from neighboring countries. The broader issue is
that national development without job opportunities for the Bhutanese is not compatible with the
country’s  priority  goal  of  self-reliance.  It  is  also  difficult  for  Bhutan  to  limit  the  number  of
expatriate laborers as it will result in a loss of competitiveness of Bhutanese labor in the medium
to long term, which is again not compatible with the Government’s goal of self-reliance.

competitive,  with  a  focus  on  making  educated  youth  better  prepared  for  private  sector

IV.  THE PROJECT
A.  Rationale
46.  Since 1981, Bhutan has experienced robust economic growth while diversifying from a
traditional subsistence economy to a modern economy. This growth has been accompanied by
significant growth in modern sector employment, particularly in construction, manufacturing, and
business services. However, Bhutanese youth lack appropriate skills, and have been unable to
take advantage of these employment opportunities. Substantial investment in basic education
over the past several decades has produced a large cohort of educated youth, many of whom
have  remained  unemployed  despite  the  existing  employment  opportunities.  Unless  these
graduates can be provided with employable skills, they face an uncertain future with little

will be unable to utilize its domestic human resources to promote national development, and
social problems associated with a growing pool of unemployed urban youth are bound to
increase. The TVET system is poorly positioned to provide the high-quality training required by
the growing private sector. The Government plans to upgrade the TVET system by improving
the policy framework of the system; upgrading the quality and relevance of training; expanding
access, particularly for women and the rural villagers who currently do not have access to skills
training; and improving the system’s responsiveness to private sector demands.
B.  Objective and Scope
47.  The project seeks to improve the quality and relevance of the TVET system to enable it
to  provide  employment-oriented  basic  skills  training  to  new  school  graduates,  unemployed
youth, domestic laborers, people in rural areas, particularly women and the poor. Such training
will give the target groups access to employment and income-generating opportunities and will
expand the capacity to provide skilled human resources to promote private sector growth as
well as to meet the demand for skilled workers in the private sector. To achieve the objective,
the  Project  will  (i)  strengthen  the  institutional  capacity  for  policy  making,  planning,  and
coordination in the TVET sector, and for delivering basic skills training relevant to the market
needs and commensurate with the capacity of the beneficiaries; (ii) increase access to basic
skills  training  by  expanding  the  TVET  system  to  include  community-based  programs,  and
rehabilitating existing and establishing new facilities; (iii) improve the quality of basic skills
training by increasing links with the private sector; and (iv) promote effective utilization of basic
skills by developing employment guidance and placement services. The Project will have three
components.
1.  Institutional Capacity Building (Component 1)
48.  Policy  Development.  To  accomplish  sustainable  TVET  reforms  in  basic  skills
development, the priority is to develop a mechanism in the TVET sector to formulate skills
development policies and strategies; and then plan, develop, and implement an employment-
oriented TVET system in a cost-effective manner in close coordination with private sector
enterprises, private training institutes, and relevant government agencies. NTTA will take the
lead role in building the employment-oriented TVET system. Before implementing the Project,
the ADTA consultants and consultants financed by the Government of Germany will assist
NTTA in developing appropriate TVET policies, including a national vocational qualifications
policy, equitable access promotion policy, private sector partnership policy, and cost sharing
policy. The team of consultants will assist NTTA and concerned ministries to prepare a draft
TVET  promotion  policy  agenda  for  the  Government  to  implement  during  the  Project.  The
policies aim at providing NTTA with a rationale for (i) establishing linkages with the private
sector; (ii) strengthening management capacity to support and administer key committees, units,
and training institutes; (iii) supporting the delivery of training packages; skill testing through
private training institutes and enterprises as well as its own training institutes; and (iv) improving
other activities to effectively ensure a participatory process with junior high and high school
teachers  and  students  and  international  aid  agencies.  NTTA  will  implement  workshops  to
consult  with  various  stakeholders  and  disseminate  information  for  the  policy  formulation
process.

considering  the  demand  orientation  of  the  training  programs,  it  is  important  for  NTTA  to
accelerate and strengthen the participatory process by involving employers. NTTA will actively
promote  the  new  framework  in  the  market  through  various  publicity  programs,  such  as
contacting employers directly and disseminating relevant information to the public to ensure the
transparency and accountability of the reform process.
50.  Management Strengthening. Using modern computer and network technologies, the
Project will assist NTTA in developing an effective management control system commensurate
with NTTA's capacity in terms of number of staff, their skill levels, and office facilities. The
management control system will include (i) a management accounting and budgeting system for
NTTA’s internal use to control activities of training institutes and key units by activity-linked
budgeting, in addition to the national financial accounting system required by laws for reporting
to external authorities such as the Ministry of Finance or relevant stakeholders; (ii) a cost
accounting  system  required  by  the  cost  sharing  policy  to  verify  the  cost-effectiveness  of
individual training programs to be consigned to the private sector; (iii) a financial management
system to establish and monitor cash flows; (iv) a cash management system with a clear, built-
in internal control system; and (v) an asset and inventory administration system to account for
timely repairs and replacement of equipment and efficient inventory control of spare parts and
training material. The cash management system, including fee collections and payments, is
important because the education and skills training systems have been operated virtually free of
charge to students and the nationwide retail banking network is weak. Institutionalization of the
management control system will be closely monitored and strengthened by annual management
review by the consultants and NTTA. The international fellowships and regional and subregional
training programs will be implemented.
51.  Alumni Administration System (AAS). One of the commonly observed weaknesses of
the TVET system is lack of alumni data due to the mobility and diversity of graduates, which
inhibit the authorities from tracking the career of trainees after their graduation and establishing
a feedback loop to improve the TVET system. The AAS will create a network among graduates
to help exchange work experience and employment information.
52.  To  support  implementation  activities,  the  Project  will  provide  consulting  services,
equipment, furniture, and vehicles.

53.  Promotion of Equitable Access. The equitable access promotion policy will enhance
access to basic skills training by expanding the existing institutional facilities and widening the
choice of trades, providing flexible delivery modes, and locating facilities in more accessible
locations. Particular attention will be given to reach women in rural areas who did not have
access  to  social  services  including  skills  training  due  to  poor  roads  and  lack  of  other
infrastructure.  With  the  recent  improvements  on  the  road  network  (footnote  13)  and  rural
electrification (footnote 12), basic skills training is now accessible to rural villagers, especially
women  who  play  an  important  role  in  the  rural  community  of  Bhutan.  NTTA  will  conduct
equitable access promotion activities, including in-house induction training programs for NTTA

and its institute staff, interim evaluation of the achievements on increased access in each
institute, and follow-up training incorporating gender sensitization programs for trainers.
54.  Training Institutes. The capacity of RTI’s facilities, programs, and course delivery will
be strengthened and expanded. Competency-based modular-style training packages will be
introduced  to  make  training  delivery  more  flexible  and  training  content  more  employment
oriented. To improve internal efficiency, the current instructor-student ratio will be increased
from 1:8 to 1:20 by the end of the Project. Expanding the RTI main campus will increase
enrollment from about 300 to 750 students by the end of the Project. Refurbishing training

55.  Two new RTI extensions will be established: one in Trashigang in the eastern part of
Bhutan and the other in Punakha in northern Bhutan. The extensions will increase training
capacity by about 320 enrollees. A building construction training center (CTC) including a
production unit to be established in Paro will have the capacity to train 100 equivalent full-time
trainees and workers per annum. In Thimphu, an Auto Repair Training Center (ARTC) will be
established, with capacity to train 15 equivalent full-time trainees and workers. NDTI, currently

strengthen apprenticeship programs, consign training programs to accredited private institutes,

annum.

training. CAU will offer general basic skills training and identify and give training in village-

use of computer and network technologies in developing the curriculum and teaching and
learning materials. However, the teaching aids and textbooks will also be prepared as printed
material for use at the training sites.

disparities are comparatively narrow, and women are equal to men in many aspects. However,
unfavorable  changes  in  the  gender  balance  have  occurred  in  the  course  of  the  country’s
modernization and industrialization. The country’s rapid growth has been achieved through
                  
46  Bhutan: Environment Policy 2000.

25
construction work, which favors male employment. Consequently, the TVET system has been
affected by the demand for skills training, which tends to favor men.
91.  Poverty in Bhutan does not take on the characteristics commonly found in South Asia.
The  Government’s  liberal  and  generous  social  policies  have  helped  to  ensure  that  as  it
modernizes, the population has had wide and equitable access to social services including
provision  of  free  education  and  medical  services.  This  concept,  known  as  Gross  National
Happiness in Bhutan, has been a factor in ensuring that poverty rates do not significantly grow
or deepen as the country develops.
92.  The shift from a traditional to an industrial economy and the Government’s priority on
private sector development have precipitated some inequalities as mentioned in the document
Bhutan 2020: A Vision for Peace, Prosperity and Happiness (footnote 21), which stated that
“although reliable data are not available, evidence suggests that income disparities appear to be
on the increase.” Signs of increasing unemployment, particularly among urban youth, show the
potential risk of increasing income inequalities.
93.  Social  analysis  suggests  the  need  to  strengthen  human  development  to  improve
equitable  participation  in  the  country’s  national  development  and  income  generation
opportunities.  The  Project  incorporates  specific  measures  to  extend  access  to  basic  skills
development opportunities by developing, implementing, and monitoring the equitable access
promotion policy to address the male-oriented TVET structure and poor access to training for
rural villagers, particularly women in rural communities. Under the policy, the Government will
introduce gender considerations in developing curriculum and training packages and establish
the CAU to introduce outreach programs. The Project also will meet industry demands for
employable skills by developing relevant training programs based on the national vocational
qualifications policy and skills standards.
94.  The thematic classification of the Project is human development.
V.  PROJECT JUSTIFICATION
A.  Economic Benefits and Project Sustainability
95.  The country’s main benefit from a redeveloped TVET will be the enhanced employability
of educated youth, particularly women, in the private sector. Economic benefits will also accrue
from the enhanced productivity and competitiveness of Bhutanese workers and the beneficial
effects of the Project on health and quality of life through better income opportunities. Extending
training facilities to rural areas will benefit those who did not have access to skills training,
particularly women. Systematic data for the relative earnings of workers in the enterprise sector
are not available. Nonquantifiable long-run indirect benefits will primarily be improved market-
relevant skills of Bhutanese workers.
96.  In  addition  to  the  TVET  policies  that  NTTA  will  introduce  to  coordinate  training
provisions, the Government will (i) introduce policies to reform TVET, and (ii) encourage the
private sector to utilize the skills acquired by Bhutanese trainees and to participate in TVET. The
Project addresses the need for cost sharing through several measures: consigning training
program implementation to private training providers, and providing on-demand base training
programs and apprenticeship programs. The Government will gradually introduce fees for social
services,  including  education.  NTTA  will  introduce  a  cost  accounting  system  and  start

26
developing a training fee system. The Project segregates capital and recurrent cost items to
support financial sustainability upon completion of the Project. The Government agreed to fully
finance the recurrent costs throughout project implementation to avoid any financing gap in
operating and maintaining the project facilities at the end of the loan utilization period (Appendix
4).
97.  IPU  will  enable  direct  contact  with  employers  to  receive  feedback  and  identify  the
needed training programs and delivery modes and to disseminate information to make the
TVET reform process transparent and accountable; LMIS will establish an objective and reliable
market  information  system;  ITC  will  directly  capture  the  training  needs  of  employers;  the
management control to link the achievement of project targets with individual performance; and
the  location  of  new  training  institutes  that  provide  students  better  access  to  training  and
employment.  CAU  will  establish  outreach  activities  utilizing  the  road  and  electrification
infrastructure recently provided under ADB assistance; and JPO will provide career guidance
and  job  placement  services  for  private  sector  employment,  designed  appropriately  to  be
commensurate with the social context and absorptive capacity of the Government. The Project
will assist NTTA to strengthen the TVET system by adding necessary policy framework and
facilities.
98.  The plans for the new training institutes will promote improved cost-effectiveness and
sustainable operations. Previously the Government’s in-house skills trainers viewed training as
a matter of supplying predetermined allocations of workers of particular skills types, trained in
the traditional established general requirements of the user ministries and agencies. However,
that function and principal client have now changed and long-term survival will depend on
ensuring graduate employment mainly in the private sector, by meeting the expressed training
needs of industries and their preferred training modalities (time, place, length and levels). This
will require rapidly establishing formal links with industry and redesigning programs to meet the
industry-determined national skills standards. To facilitate this change, the Project provides for a
management information system (MIS) and development of LMIS within NEB, and the gathering
of system data on training and outcomes through longitudinal tracer studies of graduates. It also
provides for the establishment of IPU at NTTA to provide central coordination for industry
linkages.
99.  Under component 2, RTI is to be substantially upgraded and expanded. Since RTI is
already well-established with basic skills training infrastructure and trained staff, and is widely
known, it is more cost-effective to improve its capacity to be the core and base of NTTA’s
expansion than to build that up from zero elsewhere. RTI’s location at Phuentsholing, close to
the largest center of manufacturing and other industrial activity in the country, makes it a most
appropriate location for major expansion in certified basic skills training. Due to the high land
cost in Thimphu (about 30 times higher than in other regional centers), ARTC may be located
on leased premises if it is in Thimphu. Punakha was chosen as the site of the new RTI
extension campus and NDTI because (i) it is near Thimphu, (ii) it is the center of a wood-based
industry, and (iii) it has abundant suitable land and a climate that allows year-round operation of
NTDI. Paro was chosen as the site of CTC because (i) it is the second largest center around
Thimphu, and thus adds to a suitable distribution of training facilities throughout the region, and
(ii) it is a major center of the building and construction industry. The other RTI extension campus
is to be located in Trashigang in eastern Bhutan. Trashigang is an important emerging center of
enterprise activity, and equally important, is one of the most densely populated parts of the
country and as yet has no basic skills training facilities nearby, except at TIZC.

27
100.  The current unit cost of providing skills development training in the different institutes is
based on a pattern of instructor staffing and program provision, which is essentially a legacy of
the earlier “government training center” role of RTI. NTTA is aware that the required reform will
necessitate greater operational and financial efficiency. It has been recommended that unit cost
data become a regular part of NTTA’s MIS to allow use of systematic comparative analysis as a
regular tool for management. Project targets are predicated on the staged adoption of more
cost-effective instructor-trainee ratios from the 2000 baseline ratio of 1:8 to 1:20 eventually.
101.  The  Project  is  considered  financially,  economically,  and  institutionally  viable  and
sustainable. It will adopt cost-effective training methodologies and appropriate private sector
linkages to ensure sustained demand for its training services.
B. Social Dimensions
102.  The  Project  has  been  prepared  in  a  participatory  manner,  with  representatives  of
relevant government agencies, private enterprises, NGOs, major aid agencies such as GTZ and
UNDP, male and female students and trainees, heads of training institutes and school teachers
in three major national workshops, consultations with communities by the PPTA consultants,
and extensive field investigations and site visits by staff during the PPTA review. The PPTA
conducted social surveys and an independent social analysis by an international social expert.
The PPTA also incorporated the findings from the recent ADB-financed poverty assessment and
analysis in Bhutan.47
103.  The Project will benefit four client groups: (i) graduates of junior high and high schools;
(ii) unemployed educated youth, particularly in urban areas; (iii) workers who need to improve
their skills or to certify their skills attainment at work to secure continued employment and
income improvement; and (iv) rural villagers who did not have access to skills training. By
developing relevant training modules with various modalities for delivering skills training to its
client groups, the Project will ensure total enrollment in formal and nonformal skills training of
around 1,500 annually or training for about 5,300 trainees by the end of the Project.
104.  In rural areas, CAU will cover at least 210 rural villagers annually with mobile training
programs  to  improve  the  shortage  of  basic  skills  needed  for  day-to-day  maintenance  of
community facilities and provide income generating opportunities to the villagers, particularly
poor women. Job seekers will receive employment counseling and job placement services.
Considering  the  relatively  poor  status  of  gender  balance  in  TVET  enrollment,  the  Project
addresses the need to enhance the availability of skills training for women through diversified
training subjects, female-friendly facilities such as toilets and girls hostels; training in gender
sensitization training for planners, trainers, and employment and job placement counselors; and
publicity work to attract more females to the training so that at least 30 percent of the total TVET
enrollment will be women by the end of the Project without imposition of an artificial female
quota  that  often  adversely  affects  the  intended  benefits  to  the  participants  and  project
sustainability.  Communities  in  rural  areas  will  be  encouraged  to  participate  in  the  training
program, not only for general skills but also for skills geared to develop special community
products  for  income  earnings.    NTTA,  being  aware  of  ongoing  and  planned  village  skills
development activities by other agencies, will explore the linkages and coordination through
CAU to maximize physical coverage without duplicating investments.

C. NTTA’s Institutional Capacity
105.  The  current  institutional  capacity  for  TVET  is  weak  due  to  inadequate  policies,
insufficient management skills and staff; and lack of a demand-based training system, linkages
with the private sector, and capital to update the obsolete facilities in NTTA. The Project’s input
to policy development and management capacity will strengthen NTTA.
106.  At the policy level, the Project will support the strengthening of the new TVET system by
introducing  four  key  TVET  policies:  the  national  vocational  qualifications  policy,  equitable
access promotion policy, private sector partnership policy, and cost sharing policy to provide
direction and rationale in decision making, training operations, and other activities to establish
and operate the training system.
107.  At the management level, before the start of the Project, an introductory management
training program using a participatory approach will be implemented under the ADTA. The
Project  will  promote  business  process  reengineering  within  NTTA  by  establishing  a
management cycle linking planning, implementation, and evaluation into an annual operational
cycle  and  introducing  management  by  objectives,  a  model  that  is  widely  used  in  modern
competitive organizations. NTTA will assign operational targets with appropriate budgets to
each staff at the beginning of the year. Individual targets will be set by disaggregating the
annual targets of the Project. With this system, NTTA will link overall project performance to
individual performance, which will be evaluated at year-end. Together with appropriate staff
development  programs,  the  Project  will  strengthen  NTTA’s  performance  by  integrating  the
individual work programs with the overall organizational goal.
D. Project Risk
108.  Timely Implementation. The Project starts with (i) development of policies and physical
facilities followed by (ii) initial implementation and (iii) review and updates to fully institutionalize
the new TVET system in a sustainable manner. Therefore, initial delay in developing and
adopting new policies by the Government, or in civil works and installation of training equipment
will affect project sustainability because it will reduce the time to fully institutionalize the new
TVET system.
109.  For timely implementation of the policies and to manage the TVET reform process, the
Government  agreed  to  start  policy  formulation  for  the  Project  under  the  ADTA,  which
commenced in April 2001 for five months. A task force, including representatives of concerned
ministries and private sector industries (to prepare policy recommendations under the ADTA),
will become the PSC to ensure the continuity of the policy formulation process. In assisting with
policy formulation and preparation of a sector plan to incorporate in the 9FYP, the ADTA also
aims  at  developing  NTTA’s  capacity  for  interministerial  coordination  in  formulating  and
implementing several policies to be developed under the Project. The management component
of the ADTA will strengthen NTTA’s capacity for managing the proposed institutional reform. To
assist in physical implementation-civil works and procuring and installing equipment-the Project
will utilize (i) an international consultant as chief implementation expert to assist PIU in civil
works,  procurement  planning  and  contract  awards,  and  key  day-to-day  tasks;  and  (ii)
independent  civil  works  site  supervisors  to  closely  monitor  and  follow  up  progress  and
installation and testing of equipment on site. The key ADB consultants including a management
expert, chief implementation expert, industry liaison and publicity expert, and job placement
expert will be fielded intermittently to support the institutionalization process as indicated in the
implementation schedule (Appendix 9).

29
110.  Demand for Skilled Labor. Sustained growth of the private sector with rising demand
for trained labor is one of the important assumptions for the success of the Project. Although the
Project will provide skills to Bhutanese with career aspirations for working in the private sector, if
labor demand shrinks due to insufficient growth of the private sector, the Project’s development
impact and sustainability will be weakened.
111.  The COS indicates the shortage of skilled Bhutanese as one of the five constraints to the
growth of the private sector, and hence the economic growth of Bhutan. To avoid the future risk
of insufficient demand for skilled workers, ADB should promote concerted efforts and policy
dialogue with the Government in various sectors to promote the economic growth of the country
including support to (i) improve policy setting and financial intermediation; (ii) improve road
transport and power supply; and (iii) strengthen vocational, technical, and basic skills during the
project implementation period as indicated in ADB’s country assistance plan for 2001-2003.
112.  To effectively cope with the emerging needs from the growing private sector, the new
TVET system should have management that effectively responds to the changing operational
environment. To ensure efficacy and efficiency of the TVET system, the Project will strengthen
management by (i) providing modern managerial skills and control system; (ii) institutionalizing
working linkages with private enterprises, including setting up such organizations as ITCs and
IPU and promoting private sector participation in training by apprenticeship and the training
consignment system; and (iii) developing a reliable labor market monitoring and assessment
system. Mechanisms to enhance private sector participation in the new TVET system are
summarized in Appendix 14.
113.  Demand for Training by Educated Youth. The attitude of the educated Bhutanese
toward both a public sector career and private sector employment is changing. Due to the
limited prospects of  (i) being recruited into the public service due to the Government policy to
limit the size of the civil service, and (ii) finding suitable employment in the industry sector due to
lack of employable skills, Bhutanese youth are already seeking basic skills training. To further
promote the change in attitude, the Government in the mid-1990s established NEB to assist in
job placements in the private sector, and introduced work value education throughout the
general education system. In support of the proposed new Government policies, an IPU will be
established in NTTA under the Project to implement the school-industry exchange programs
and  several  publicity  works  by  organizing  workshops  and  utilizing  newspaper,  radio,  and
television  programs,  web  and  e-mails,  and  other  media;  and  JPO  in  NEB  to  offer  career
guidance and job placement services for employment in the private sector. To promote work
value education at the school level, the Project will also strengthen vocational center facilities in
secondary schools nationwide.
114.  Other Demand-Related Risks. In addition to these demand-side risks (para. 110-113),
other  risks  for  project  sustainability  exist:  the  inflexibility  of  the  training  provided,  and  the
changing demands of the private sector as it develops and progresses towards a modern
industrial economy (policy risk), or the capital requirements necessary to replace equipment due
to changing demand (capital risk). It is crucial that the training system develop the ability to
quickly adapt and evolve with the changing requirements of industry. This requires strong
linkages  with  the  private  sector.  To  institutionalize  private  sector  linkages,  the  Project  will
establish four key TVET policies including the private sector partnership policy at the outset.
The capital-intensive nature of TVET has been deemed an inherent weakness of the TVET
system. The Project will challenge this risk by introducing innovative cost sharing schemes such
as consigning training operations to private sector institutes by contract. Under the consignment
system, NTTA will develop training programs and, if necessary, procure training equipment for

30
rent, while the contracted private training institutes will use their own premises to conduct
training using the programs and equipment rented from NTTA.

steering committee (PSC), with a composition similar to the interministerial task

vocational qualifications policy; (b) an equitable access promotion policy; (c) a

conditions in the private sector (NEB); (b) a skills utilization policy including
